abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Private Enterprise Development Project
            (PEDP) in Togo. The main objectives of PEDP were to: (i)
            promote economic growth and increase employment through
            policy changes, technical assistance and financial
            mechanisms for enhancing private enterprises, with special
            attention to SMEs and the artisanal sector; and (ii) reduce
            the role of the Government in the productive sectors through
            technical assistance to assist in the government's
            ongoing program of parastatal enterprise privatization.
            Bank's performance was satisfactory. Borrower's
            performance was deficient. The key lessons learned were as
            follows: (i) any follow-up project for private enterprise
            development should include a detailed private sector
            assessment, coordination of its program with those of other
            donors, and the full commitment of the Government to both
            its objectives and its design; (ii) commercial banks and
            professional associations of enterprises should take the
            leadership role in any institutional structure developed for
            private investmnent promotion; (iii) the relationship
            between IDA and the Borrower should be dynamic and flexible
            keeping communication channels open, to allow for project
            changes in the case where the original design does not work
            well in practice, or is overtaken by events; (iv) the design
            of a line of credit to commercial banks should be as simple
            as possible avoiding layers of approval that are not
            absolutely necessary and may very well deter the interest of
            investment enterprises and commercial banks; and (v) it is
            important to find appropriate modalities for providing
            viable institutional support to the informal sector, which
            can potentially constitute a dynamic and productive segment
            of the economy.
